thread.title: Devils defeat New York Rangers, 2-1, in OT | Rapid reaction - NJ.com
thread.title_full: Devils defeat New York Rangers, 2-1, in OT | Rapid reaction - NJ.com

title: Devils defeat New York Rangers, 2-1, in OT | Rapid reaction - NJ.com
text:
NEW YORK — Lee Stempniak scored at 3:07 of 3-on-3 overtime to lift the Devils to their first victory of the season, a 2-1 triumph over the New York Rangers Sunday at Madison Square Garden. 
It was the first NHL victory for Devils coach John Hynes. 
Rick Nash nearly won it after 23 seconds of overtime. He drive through the crease and the puck nearly crossed the line before Devils captain Andy Greene cleared it. 
Greene sent up Kyle Palmieri, who was robbed by Henrik Lundqvist at 2:25 of OT. 
HIGHLIGHTS 
Hynes gets his first NHL win and the game puck. 
Adam Henrique scored his team-leading third goal of the season. . @AdamHenrique knows a thing or two about scoring during the Hudson River Rivalry. #NJDvsNYR pic.twitter.com/DgBMuipFiw — New Jersey Devils (@NHLDevils) October 18, 2015 
The way the game started, it could have been a blowout. But, as they have at various points this season, the Devils battled back to make it interesting. 
Lee Stempniak came close to scoring a shorthanded goal with 7:54 left in the third. Henrik Lundqvist had to make a quick pad save to keep the game tied. 
Sergey Kalinin has shown some promise. Needs to start producing. 
LOWLIGHTS 
The Devils' power play (0-for-3), which had been tied for fifth in the league entering the game. They couldn't get much to the net, failing to get any shots on goal during a two-man advantage for 1:36 early in the third period. 
Defenseman David Schlemko struggled in the first period. The Devils have now given up the first goal in all five games this season. 
RELATED: How many games will the Devils win this season? Vote 
FIGHTS 
Kyle Palmieri and Kevin Klein fought at center ice with 46.1 seconds left in the fierst period. Klein landed most of the punches after the two exchanged slashes. 
HEALTHY SCRATCHES 
Rangers:D Dylan McIlrath, LW Tanner Glass, RW Emerson Etem. 
NOTABLE 
Palmieri's fight with Klein was the first for the Devils this season. The Devils had 22 fights last season. 
Patrik Elias remains out with a right knee issue. He has yet to practice with the team, but is moving closer to a return. 
"He continues to make progress," coach John Hynes reported. "He's skating more and more. Things look like they're going in the right direction. Time frame wise, not yet, but it's definitely going in the right direction as of now." 
With the team staying in a Times Square hotel, several Devils players walked to Madison Square Garden Sunday morning. 
THE WEEK AHEAD 
Tuesday: Devils vs. Arizona Coyotes at Prudential Center, MSG, WFAN-AM 660, WFAN-FM 101.9, 7 p.m. 
Thursday: Devils vs. Ottawa Senators at Canadian Tire Centre, MSG Plus, WFAN-AM 660, WFAN-FM 101.9, 7:30 p.m. 
Saturday: Devils vs. Devils vs. Buffalo Sabres at First Niagara Center, MSG Plus, WFAN-AM 660, WFAN-FM 101.9, 7 p.m. — NHL (@NHL) October 18, 2015 
Rich Chere may be reached at rchere@njadvancemedia.com . Follow him on Twitter @Ledger_NJDevils . Find NJ.com on Facebook New York Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist makes a save against the Devils Sunday. (Adam Hunger/AP) Rich Chere | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
